awd_titl_txt: Earth Education for Sustainable Societies Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
Current priorities in science education include efforts to engage students in scientific reasoning and using the knowledge and practices of science to understand natural phenomena and constructively respond to local and global challenges. This project responds to these priorities by bringing together representatives of diverse geoscience education communities in a workshop to identify high-priority needs for strengthening geoscience education broadly, and to initiate plans for addressing the identified needs through curriculum development and teacher professional development activities. In the context of global and local environmental challenges, workshop participants will consider educational priorities associated with understanding Earth systems, promoting geoscience literacy, and exploring sustainable solutions.  Workshop participants will also consider desirable skills students might acquire for future employment in the sciences, with particular emphasis on ways to diversity the population of students prepared to address issues of sustainability. Working groups established during the workshop will continue after the workshop, using virtual meeting tools to continue collaborative efforts.

This 3-day Earth Education for Sustainable Societies workshop will extend and enhance activities initiated by the previously funded STEP Center: InTeGrate: Interdisciplinary Teaching of Geoscience for a Sustainable Future (NSF award 1125331). The Center has developed curriculum materials for teaching geoscience in the context of societal issues, and it has initiated teacher professional development programs and communities of practice. This project will build on those efforts by bringing together participants in the previous project with other researchers and educators within and outside the geoscience education community who want to engage in teaching, research, or outreach activities related to learning about sustainability and Earth systems. A comprehensive recruitment strategy will be used to ensure broad diversity of disciplinary perspectives, cultural perspectives, and institutional affiliations. Prior to the workshop, participants will be invited to attend a Town Hall and or webinars to gain background information and an overview of project resources and expectations. By providing multiple ways of preparing for and participating in the planned workshop, the project will both expand and diversify the existing community of practice and promote ongoing collaborations to address high-priority needs identified by workshop participants. Participants will be encouraged to form ongoing Working Groups and use virtual meeting tools to continue discussions and collaborative efforts.

The Discovery Research PreK-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by PreK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Earth science education that addresses sustainability is driven by the recognition that human demands on the Earth system through natural resource use and urbanization have put at risk our ability to live sustainably on our planet and that hazards like storms and earthquakes exacerbate societal inequities. Geoscientists play a strong role in studying, communicating, and finding solutions to modern societal challenges, not the least of which is building sustainable societies. Additionally, geoscientists must be prepared for- and invite collaborations with a variety of disciplines, community groups and institutions that help educate the public at large. In an effort to better prepare the geoscience community for such challenges, the Interdisciplinary Teaching about Earth for a Sustainable Future (InTeGrate) initiative created and implemented use of freely available curriculum designed to increase students’ capacity to understand and solve societal issues related to the geosciences and beyond. In doing so, more than 110,000 students at more than 1000 institutions of higher education learned geoscience content in the context of living on Earth successfully, sustainably and justly. Students included those in majors leading to the geoscience workforce, and many more who can incorporate the context of sustainable societies in other careers, including those from traditionally marginalized groups and future teachers. 

 

Following the culmination of InTeGrate’s ambitious Earth science education initiative, scientists and educators met in 2019 to prioritize ways in which education about Earth can build on ways to foster sustainable societies. The Earth Education for Sustainable Societies (EESS) workshop benefited from participation by educators and emerging leaders from K-12 teachers, faculty from higher education, and leaders from informal learning environments, along with educators in government agencies that support scientific data collection and student and public outreach. Participants mapped out a new community vision for EESS, prioritized efforts and began work on 20 new projects to make progress in achieving that vision. The EESS vision statement is: 

 

Earth education for sustainable societies engages all learners and empowers communities to develop relationships and solutions for environmental resilience. 

 

Examples of activities developed at the workshop include establishing a framework for student-stakeholder environmental participatory action, engaging institutions in higher education in leading sustainability practices, writing a freshwater literacy document and developing a guide for teaching about energy. 


Educating students in K12 grades and in higher education contributes to improving the geoscience literacy of the general public and leads to a stronger workforce in the geosciences and beyond. In doing so, students will become experts who can provide scientific knowledge, systems thinking, and are skilled in solving interdisciplinary problems that are critical to addressing societal grand challenges in environmental sustainability.
